LEVEL.Name: INDEX
LEVEL.Comment: Since SAP DB needs no reorganization, you do not have to modify the memory characteristics for indexes. The SQL statement ALTER INDEX is known in SAP DB, but has different syntax and semantics to Oracle.

LEVEL.Name: SESSION
LEVEL.Comment:
NLS_SORT, NLS_LANGUAGE, NLS_DATE_LANGUAGE, NLS_DATE_FORM
are supported (?, please feel free to test it)

LEVEL.Name: TABLE
LEVEL.Comment:
The SQL statement ALTER TABLE is known in SAP DB, but has different syntax and semantics to Oracle.
#1 The variants PCTFREE, PCTUSED, INITRANS, MAXTRANS, STORAGE, DROP, and ALLOCATE are meaningless in SAP DB and are rejected. #2 SAP DB cannot deactivate constraints. SAP DB therefore ignores the specification of DISABLE. #3 SAP DB cannot delete any UNIQUE constraints using the DROP clause. The DROP INDEX statement must be used for this instead. #4 When columns are inserted, SAP DB automatically inserts these columns in all view tables that use the "*" in the <select_list>, in order to identify all columns of the table.

LEVEL.Name: NOT NULL
LEVEL.Comment:
This statement "NOT NULL" is not supported in 7.3!
Unused existing tests in: ALTER_TABLE_positive.xml No.: 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15 and 16

LEVEL.Name: COLUMN REF CONSTRAINT
LEVEL.Comment:
in this level are tested: REFERENCES ... REFERENCES ... ON DELETE SET NULL REFERENCES ... ON DELETE CASCADE
there are more negative tests on the constraint_clause in the level CREATE/TABLE/COLUMN/COLUMN CONSTRAINT/REFERENCES
SCOPE IS ... is not supported by SAP DB WITH ROWID is not supported by SAP DB

LEVEL.Name: TRIGGER
LEVEL.Comment: SAP DB cannot deactivate triggers. The SQL statement ALTER TRIGGER is therefore not accepted by SAP DB.

LEVEL.Name: VIEW
LEVEL.Comment: SAP DB always keeps view tables in an executable state. The SQL statement ALTER VIEW is therefore not necessary, and is not accepted

LEVEL.Name: DBPROC
LEVEL.Comment: there is an extra catalogue enholding dbproc tests

LEVEL.Name: INDEX
LEVEL.Comment:
Creating Indexes without additional parameters = not unique and ascending
The SQL statement CREATE INDEX is known in SAP DB, but has different syntax and semantics to Oracle. #1 The specification of CLUSTER <cluster>, INITRANS <integer>, MAXTRANS <integer>, TABLESPACE <tablespace>, STORAGE <storage_clause>, PCTFREE <integer>, and NOSORT is meaningless in SAP DB, but is accepted. #2 The index is generated in descending order in SAP DB when DESC is specified.

LEVEL.Name: ASC
LEVEL.Comment: Creating Indexes with explicit ASC statement

LEVEL.Name: DESC
LEVEL.Comment: Creating Indexes with desc statement

LEVEL.Name: UNIQUE
LEVEL.Comment: Using "create unique index..." to gurantee uniqueness of a indexed field

LEVEL.Name: NULL
LEVEL.Comment: NULL values do not affected uniqueness

LEVEL.Name: SEQUENCE
LEVEL.Comment: SAP DB accepts the SQL statement CREATE SEQUENCE with the following syntax restrictions: the options CACHE and ORDER are meaningless for SAP DB.

LEVEL.Name: SYNONYM
LEVEL.Comment: SAP DB does not permit any synonyms for sequences, database procedures or synonyms. At the time of execution of the SQL statement CREATE SYNONYM, the object for which the synonym is defined must exist. The current user must have at least one privilege for this object.

LEVEL.Name: TABLE
LEVEL.Comment:
The SQL statement CREATE TABLE is known in SAP DB, but has different syntax and semantics to Oracle.
#1 The specification of PCTFREE <integer>, PCTUSED <integer>, INITRANS <integer>, MAXTRANS <integer>, TABLESPACE <tablespace>, STORAGE <storage clause>, and CLUSTER <cluster> is allowed by the syntax, but all are meaningless in SAP DB. #2 SAP DB ignores the specification of DISABLE. #3 If a subquery is specified, SAP DB does not generate NOT NULL constraints. #4 In Oracle, each table row has a unique address that can be accessed as ROWID. The row can be addressed directly by using the ROWID. The ROWID also exists if the table has a key. Such an address is not available in SAP DB, because the rows are always addressed using the key. Table option ROWID can be used to better imitate Oracle behavior. This has the following effect: The table implicitly received key column ROWID from data type RAW(8). This column is usually invisible and can only be selected using the ROWID function. - If the CREATE TABLE statement contains a key_definition, an index with the UNIQUE attribute that corresponds to the key definition is generated.
In this way, a row has a ROWID and can be selected with the ROWID and the key.

LEVEL.Name: COLUMN REF CONSTRAINT
LEVEL.Comment:
in this level are tested: REFERENCES ... REFERENCES ... ON DELETE SET NULL REFERENCES ... ON DELETE CASCADE
there are more negative tests on the constraint_clause in the level CREATE/TABLE/COLUMN/COLUMN CONSTRAINT/REFERENCES
SCOPE IS ... is not supported by SAP DB WITH ROWID is not supported by SAP DB

LEVEL.Name: ORDER BY
LEVEL.Comment: 09-2002 SAP DB 7.3 does not support it

LEVEL.Name: ORDER BY
LEVEL.Comment: 09-2002 SAP DB 7.3 does not support it

LEVEL.Name: ORDER BY
LEVEL.Comment: 09-2002 SAP DB 7.3 does not support it

LEVEL.Name: TABLESPACE
LEVEL.Comment: schema object TABLESPACE is not supported by SAP DB. Nevertheless syntax is accepted by SAP DB, but does not have any consequences.

LEVEL.Name: TRIGGER
LEVEL.Comment:
there is an extra catalogue enholding trigger tests
In SAP DB, SQL statement CREATE TRIGGER can only be used to define the triggers described in Oracle as "after row trigger".

LEVEL.Name: VIEW
LEVEL.Comment:
The SQL statement CREATE VIEW is supported in SAP DB with restricted syntax. The following restrictions exist in SAP DB for the syntax of the CREATE VIEW statement:
#1 SAP DB rejects the specification of FORCE or NOFORCE. #2 A constraint_name given to the CHECK OPTION is not stored in the database catalog. If no constraint name is specified, SAP DB does not generate a name. #3 View tables that are updatable in Oracle are not necessarily updatable in SAP DB. This is especially true for view tables whose definition contains subqueries.

LEVEL.Name: ORDER BY
LEVEL.Comment: 09-2002 SAP DB 7.3 does not support it

LEVEL.Name: ORDER BY
LEVEL.Comment: 09-2002 SAP DB 7.3 does not support it

LEVEL.Name: ORDER BY
LEVEL.Comment: 09-2002 SAP DB 7.3 does not support it

LEVEL.Name: INDEX
LEVEL.Comment:
The SQL statement DROP INDEX is accepted by SAP DB with the following restriction: because of the different namespaces for indexes, the specification of an index name does not always uniquely identify an index. In such a case, the table to which the INDEX refers must be explicitly specified.
optionally 'FORCE' is not accepted

LEVEL.Name: TABLE
LEVEL.Comment:
The SQL statement DROP TABLE is known in SAP DB but with the following syntax restrictions:
#1 All synonyms and view tables based on the table are dropped. #2 Specifying CASCADE CONSTRAINTS has no effect.

LEVEL.Name: TRIGGER
LEVEL.Comment:
Because of the different namespaces for triggers, specification of a trigger name in SAP DB does not uniquely identify the trigger.
Therefore, SAP DB only accepts the SQL statement DROP TRIGGER with the following restriction: the table that the trigger relates to must be explicitly specified.

LEVEL.Name: VIEW
LEVEL.Comment: In SAP DB, the SQL statement DROP VIEW is used to drop all the view tables and synonyms based on the view table.

LEVEL.Name: RENAME
LEVEL.Comment: The SQL statement RENAME is known in SAP DB, but behaves differently to Oracle: in SAP DB, only Basis tables can be renamed.

LEVEL.Name: INDEX
LEVEL.Comment: <INDEX_statement> ::= RENAME INDEX <old_index_name> [ON <table_name>] TO <new_index_name>

LEVEL.Name: ANALYZE
LEVEL.Comment: SAP DB only supports the variant ANALYZE TABLE for SQL statement ANALYZE. The options DELETE, VALIDATE STRUCTURE, and LIST CHAINED ROWS are not valid in SAP DB.

LEVEL.Name: DELETE [FROM]
LEVEL.Comment:
The SQL statement DELETE is supported in SAP DB with restricted syntax.
#1 If CURRENT OF <cursor> is specified, the result table must be based on an updatable table. #2 A cursor built by a join or join view table is rejected.

LEVEL.Name: INSERT INTO
LEVEL.Comment: inserts with constraints are already tested in the create table-part of the DDL

LEVEL.Name: hint
LEVEL.Comment: SAPDB does not support hints as part of an insert statements

LEVEL.Name: (column, ...)
LEVEL.Comment:
syntax of type "INSERT INTO table (column, column, ...) values_clause"
is tested under this level

LEVEL.Name: subquery
LEVEL.Comment: inserting information which has been selected from a table

LEVEL.Name: [bounds of datatypes]
LEVEL.Comment:
outstanding: alias-datatypes, user-defined type categories
as well INSERT INTO table (column, column, ...) values_clause as INSERT INTO table values_clause
are tested under this level
bounds

LEVEL.Name: char
LEVEL.Comment: tests for char datatype with codeattribute default

LEVEL.Name: char ascii
LEVEL.Comment: tests for char datatype with codeattribute ascii

LEVEL.Name: long
LEVEL.Comment: contains 'long' and 'long varchar'

LEVEL.Name: rowid
LEVEL.Comment: not testable with stedi yet

LEVEL.Name: numeric
LEVEL.Comment: not testable with stedi yet

LEVEL.Name: SELECT
LEVEL.Comment:
The SQL statement SELECT is supported in SAP DB with restricted syntax.
#1 SAP DB does not support the specification of START WITH <condition> or CONNECT BY <condition>. #2 SAP DB sometimes rejects outer joins with more than two tables in the FROM clause valid in Oracle.

LEVEL.Name: ORDER BY
LEVEL.Comment: 09-2002 SAP DB 7.3 does not support it

LEVEL.Name: ORDER BY
LEVEL.Comment: 09-2002 SAP DB 7.3 does not support it

LEVEL.Name: ORDER BY
LEVEL.Comment: 09-2002 SAP DB 7.3 does not support it

LEVEL.Name: TRUNCATE TABLE
LEVEL.Comment:
The schema object cluster is not supported by SAP DB. The SQL statement TRUNCATE CLUSTER is therefore not accepted by SAP DB.
TRUNCATE TABLE: the variants DROP STORAGE and REUSE STORAGE are meaningless because SAP DB normally behaves this way.

LEVEL.Name: UPDATE
LEVEL.Comment:
The SQL statement UPDATE is supported in SAP DB with restricted syntax.
A correlated subquery is not permitted as a subquery of a SET UPDATE clause in SAP DB. If CURRENT OF <cursor> is specified, the result table must be based on an updatable table. A cursor built by a join or join view table is rejected.

LEVEL.Name: Transaction
LEVEL.Comment: SAP DB does not accept the specification of FORCE or COMMENT for the SQL statement COMMIT.

LEVEL.Name: LOCK TABLE
LEVEL.Comment: The SQL statement LOCK TABLE is accepted by SAP DB with the following syntax restrictions: if ROW EXCLUSIVE, SHARE ROW EXCLUSIVE or EXCLUSIVE are specified, SAP DB assigns an exclusive table lock. Concurrent requests on the table are therefore not possible.

LEVEL.Name: ROLLBACK [WORK]
LEVEL.Comment:
The SQL statement ROLLBACK is supported in SAP DB with restricted syntax.
SAP DB rejects the specification of FORCE. SAP DB does not release any locks when ROLLBACK TO [SAVEPOINT] <savepoint> is specified.

LEVEL.Name: TO SAVEPOINT
LEVEL.Comment: remind: SAP DB does not release any locks when ROLLBACK TO [SAVEPOINT] <savepoint> is specified.

LEVEL.Name: LOG
LEVEL.Comment: The function LOG(x) is the natural logarithm. The function LOG(x,b) with x as argument and b as base is not supported from the ODBC or JDBC standard and can not be testet with stedi. LOG(x)=LN(x) LOG10(X)=LOG(x,10)

LEVEL.Name: LOG10
LEVEL.Comment: The function LOG(x) is the natural logarithm. The function LOG(x,b) with x as argument and b as base is not supported from the ODBC or JDBC standard and can not be testet with stedi. LOG(x)=LN(x) LOG10(X)=LOG(x,10)

LEVEL.Name: CONCAT
LEVEL.Comment: The function CONCAT(a,b) return the same like a||b or a&b

LEVEL.Name: LOG
LEVEL.Comment: The function LOG(x) is the natural logarithm. The function LOG(x,b) with x as argument and b as base is not supported from the ODBC or JDBC standard and can not be testet with stedi. LOG(x)=LN(x) LOG10(X)=LOG(x,10)

LEVEL.Name: LOG10
LEVEL.Comment: The function LOG(x) is the natural logarithm. The function LOG(x,b) with x as argument and b as base is not supported from the ODBC or JDBC standard and can not be testet with stedi. LOG(x)=LN(x) LOG10(X)=LOG(x,10)

LEVEL.Name: Optimizer
LEVEL.Comment: All optimizer tests are removed to the new catalog: SQLOptimizerCatalog.xml

LEVEL.Name: Stedi Reference Tests
LEVEL.Comment: Here you can find reference test. These test show you, what you can do with Stedi and how you can do it. Index: Simple tests: simple select............................20 Use of Phases..........................21 Check of errors.........................22 Regex and Ranges: regex in Stedi...............................1 Ranges in Stedi..........................2 Regex, Ranges and Ignores....4 Users: Connect and Release...............10 Connection parameters............12

LEVEL.Name: Simple tests
LEVEL.Comment: Here are some simple tests, which schould demonstrate the basic way of writing tests.

LEVEL.Name: Users
LEVEL.Comment:
Here are some tests which demonstrate the use of more then one user in a single test. This is useful to test e.g. authorisation and transaction.
To run these tests the test user need DBA privileges

LEVEL.Name: DB Procedures
LEVEL.Comment: These tests show the use of db procedures with Stedi.
